reviewText: I worried that this movie might be a little boring but purchased it anyway because I enjoy watching Jason Alexander and Ed Asner. I loved the small-town scenes and old-time romance between Jason's character and his wife.  These days it is hard to find a movie where a husband and wife support each other in spite of adversity and naysayers.  I love the fact that this is based on a real person.  It is heartwarming and will make you want to hug all your family.  This movie is suitable for all ages.

reviewText: Surprisingly great!  I was looking for a Christmas movie and got a lot more.  An outstanding true story that I had never heard before.  This is a piece of American history that we should all know.  Very well made and acted, the photography makes you feel you are back at the turn of the century.  The way this man ran his business should be a model for all business.  I highly recommend this for all ages!
summary: A true, inspiring story.  A must see for all ages.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a WWI period film about a man who invented and produced toys that become the wonderful classic and collectible toys for millions of children. Erector sets, science kits, chemist labs, microscopes, and more were made by this man, A. C. Gilbert who is played by Jason Alexander (The Grand, Seinfeld) in a remarkable drama role so different than those who remember him in Seinfeld.  And of course his father, played by Ed Asner, is powerfully cast and portrayed. This is based on a TRUE story.The real story here is not Christmas, although the plot is based upon that premise.  The wonderful bit of history learned about toy production during the pre-war and years of WWI are actually more of the story than Christmas.  It is a wonderful family tale, Hallmark-like, with the seal of Dove for all ages.  It is heartwarming, educational, emotional, fun, historical, fanciful, and even has a bit of holiday magic thrown in for good measure.  It is the pace and style of life that existed in teen years of the 20th century.No bonus material, just a very well done 88 minute story worth viewing. Worth owning. Worth a look by the whole family.This probably would never make a blockbuster in the theater but with it's price is a bargain value with a year-round story.  Don't wait till Christmas to enjoy this one.  Get it now.

reviewText: A.C. Gilbert (Jason Alexander) left the medical profession to pursue his dream to be in the toy business. In time - with the support of his wife and brother - his dream becomes a reality. His toy factory is successful, but then the government asks him to convert his toy factory into a munitions factory. A.C. Gilbert does not want to imagine children without toys, so the decision to honor the request is very difficult for him. After a while, he loses his peace and happiness but with a little encouragement from family he comes up with a way to make toys again while still maintaining the defense contracts.This is a touching family movie with good messages about relationships; business, sibling, husband and wife - mostly father and son. I'm glad it's available on Blu-ray; high-definition provides a much better viewing experience.Note: Blu-ray has no special features, no movie previews, no menu to select play, and when the movie is over it does not stop, but goes back to the beginning and plays again.Favorite Lines:"There's all kinds of ways to heal.""Play opens up the imagination, which then opens up new possibilities."There once was a fella named Gilly,who had dreams that some folks said were silly.But his brother and wifelove how Gilly loves life.And we know that he'll never stop dreaming.Will he?
summary: Touching Movie Based On A True Story

reviewText: Filmed before and during WWI with Jason Alexander as A.C. GILBERT.  Based on a true story how A.C. had to turn his successful toy factory into a weapons plant during WWI through the US Government.  But then how a little magic and hoilday spirit America really needs a little Christmas joy!!

reviewText: This movie is one that could be viewed anytime of the year. While the ending focuses on saving the Christmas that was almost cancelled, the rest of the movie is the story of a man who was a child at heart. Through his understanding of children and what they love, he created toys that revolutionized the industry, and brought children along into the mechanical and technological age that swept this country at the climax of WWI. I was fascinated to watch the evolution of toys that I remember as a child. My grandchildren will love this film, and maybe realize that I didn't really play with dinosaurs when I was little....we had toys then too!
summary: Holiday movie for the whole year

reviewText: This movie is about a little known piece of American history that you should know. Have you heard of Erector sets? What about the man who created them? Who would have guessed that a toy maker had such an influence on the homefront of a world war? I don't want to give away too many details that will spoil a first time viewing. I will say it's a wonderful true life lesson about the power of the heart and how important it is to hold on to what brings you hope, especially in the most difficult of times. It's not preachy. It's not heavy handed.this is meant for the whole family to enjoy, to learn from and to remember fondly.I recommend it.

reviewText: Jason Alexander plays a toymaker in this wonderful movie based on a true story set in the World War 1 era.  Alexander and the rest of cast is great and the story is very touching. A keeper!

reviewText: This movie is a little mixed. The production values are somewhat "made for TV" - the sets and costumes are sometimes a little sparse. And the writing can be a little bit simplistic at times. But the story is really good. It touches on some big issues such as the rights of citizens in a war and the relationship between business and labor. But it's done in a way that is compatible with a family holiday movie. You'll be wanting to search up video and stories about A.C. Gilbert when you're done. If you ever had an Erector Set, you'll be spellbound.
summary: Made For TV quality, but good story
Title: N/A
